abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Agricultural Manpower
            Development Project for Nepal was satisfactory. The project
            achieved most of its objectives, its institutional capacity
            has been strengthened, sustainability is likely, and both
            the Bank and Borrower performed satisfactorily. Several
            lessons can be learned from this project. First, as manpower
            projections are a tenuous basis for justifying investments
            in higher education without a supportive macroeconomic
            environment, a modular approach that allows for adjustments
            in response to changing circumstances would minimize risk.
            Second, a project that does not address the institutional
            problems of the main project institution responsible for
            meeting project objectives runs a high risk of failure.
            Third, sustainable institutional development entails the
            responsibility on the part of the institution to prove its
            relevance and effectiveness by improving and broadening its
            teaching, research, and service functions and to ensure that
            its graduates are relevant to local needs. Fourth,
            Bank-Borrower goodwill and patience, Borrower determination,
            effective leadership, and good staff teamwork can turn
            failure to relative success. Fifth, careful monitoring will
            help alert project management to potential or actual
            problems in time to allow for remedial action. Lastly, it is
            essential to mandate a systematic approach to project
            monitoring and evaluation.

docna.cdata!:
Nepal - Agricultural Manpower Development
            Project : Credit 1534 - Credit Agreement - Conformed

display_title.display_title:
Nepal - Agricultural Manpower
            Development Project : Credit 1534 - Credit Agreement - Conformed

abstracts.cdata!:
The Agricultural Manpower Development
            Project will assist His Majesty's government in
            upgrading the quality of middle level agricultural manpower.
            The project aims to achieve this by:  (a) implementing
            reforms in the training system, structure and curriculum to
            make it more relevant to the duties and responsibilities of
            agricultural extension workers and technicians; (b)
            establishing a teacher training program; and (c) improving
            training management.  The project will also assist in
            strengthening higher level agricultural training at the
            Institute of Agriculture and Animal Sciences by establishing
            a degree program (BS) in animal science and upgrading the
            existing academic, research and extension programs of the Institute.
